ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: -Professor's lecture style is somewhat meandering and unclear, and occasionally he didn't finish on time and asked us to watch the rest of the lecture out of class (given time constraints and the time spent in this class and on field trips, this was difficult). -Students sometimes left lectures a little lost and uncertain of what the key concepts were that were covered. -The textbook is fantastic and clear (again with the time constraints) it was sometimes too much to get in lectures, field trips, and readings in a week. Especially as field trips took up most fridays, all day.
Would prefer 2 or 3 weekend field trips like yale meyers instead of 7 half days. tough really getting into the half day field trips. learned so much on yale meyers trip.

Overall i felt like this class catered to the lowest common denominator of students. We spent a lot of time at the beginning of the semester and during each field trip reviewing basic things that students should have already known (species ID and stand dynamics being big ones) and that took away time that we could have been focusing on more advanced subject material. If students chose to take this class without previously taking stands or taxonomy, they should be responsible for learning that material on their own time, not wasting the time of those students that came to this class prepared with the correct material.
Fewerhalf day field trips with more full day field trips focused around field exercises and practical application.
The online lectures helped me greatly, the in class lectures were hard to follow.

About Q #1 I had trouble finding the readings on classesv2 for much of the semester. But when I did figure it out, I skimmed through most of the chapters (at least for the 2nd half of the semester). I found that the chapters could use a bit more headings to organize some topics. It seemed a bit like the content in some chapters was a lot of information that is somewhat difficult to absorb all together. It might be that additional structure might help. Some chapters are in their draft form, so that may be part of the reason for this.

Question 10 - Dr. Ashton could benefit by better organizing his in-class lectures so they are more focused and easier to follow, and should be careful to not be overly harsh and embarrass students when answering questions/responding to comments.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field trips were really great, especially the Yale Myers overnight. They were, however, too many in number, even for a four credit course, and it would have been nice to have the option to pick 5 out of 7 field trips, or something that allowed some flexibility. I really enjoyed speaking with the professor, and he's got a wealth of knowledge, but I really did struggle to follow lectures.
The silvicultural prescription and actively applying the material

I actually enjoyed the traditional lecture format for this course. Once you get the hang of how Mark lectures you end up learning a lot more than you even realize because he has a way of repeatedly revisiting topics throughout the course.
Field trip to yale meyers really like the silvics part and the types of regeneration/thinnings mark cares a lot
Field trips and hands on learning
The field trips were awesome.
Extensive content

For the most part the field trips were great. I think the Yale Myers trip was a bit ambitious in terms of what was originally planned for the weekend. We did not cover all the material but it seemed like any more would have been almost overwhelming, at least for those students (like myself) who are relatively new to forestry. In any case, I really appreciated getting to be outside, even if some of the trips were freezing.

Although they took up a lot of time, I really enjoyed the field trips for applied, field-based learning. I thought the textbook reading was very helpful to fully understand the material covered in the course.
I appreciated the depth of knowledge offered by Professor Ashton. Few forest scientists have such a global perspective.

The field trip to Yale-Myers and the second field trip to the water company land were the most valuable field trips. The silviculture textbook (assigned readings) is very well written and helped to clarify any misunderstandings about the material. For some of the lectures it was hard to understand the main point but the readings served as a great explanation.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Far too many field trips, which often interferes with other classes and non-academic commitments (e.g. on-campus jobs). I also don't like the way work is heavily stacked toward the end of the semester, with what amounts to two final exams during reading/finals week

Lecture structure and balance between at-home reading, at home viewing of supplementary lecture material, and field trips. It's just too much and it seems, that upon realizing that students were struggling to complete at home assignments, the professor decided to structure much of the final exam around extra recorded lectures and readings that no one had time to complete. Which felt, frankly, kind of mean-spirited.
Need more active application - more time coming up with silvicultural prescriptions, less lecture time

I learned a lot from the field trips just from being in the forest and listening to Mark, but it might be helpful to have some clarification on what the goals are prior to the trip. I think getting the handouts on Wednesday and being told to read them prior to the trip on Friday would be helpful in accomplishing that. Since the in-class time commitment for this course is heavy, I think I could have benefited from more specific an more manageable readings. You can get by without the readings, but they are pretty useful when you can find the time to do them. Primarily they are a great resource if I need to revisit some of the material in the future.

- the last 4 lectures on applications, wish we had guest lecturers discuss them as opposed to mark's perspective. - the course is a broad overview of so much, fairly introductory course. Although was a little frustrating in the discrepancy of understanding between those who had taken stands vs those who hadn't - could there be a follow-up advanced version that's maybe like a week long version of forest crew? For folks who don't want to be foresters, but want to work with foresters via policy/finance, etc. More hands-on as opposed to southern trip. - we never really learned how to figure out what geology/soil of a site was, even though it was 20% of prescription grade. So had to memorize new haven stuff, but seemed kinda dumb. Why not show us how to look up soils on the NRCS soilweb app? Look up the geology table? Compare it against the site. - I like how Ann structured her lectures/readings, so the readings were in the same folder as the lecture. This is mainly for the first part of the course. Once we got to the last part, the chapters of the books were pretty easy to align with lectures.
I wish we had done a bit more with the quantitative aspects of silviculture and spent more time talking about post establishment treatments
Clarity of lectures
The course needs to emphasise the importance of the readings.
Field trips were great but very time intensive. Could be made more condensed.

I was sometimes surprised by what we were tested on. I understand that we should definitely have a grasp of the big concepts, but some of the questions we were tested on seemed like such minor details. Also, we were not aware that we would be tested on things in the readings that were not covered in the lectures until one of the last week of classes. In that case I would have made more of an effort to review the readings. I thought the readings were more supplemental for those who are struggling to understand what is covered in class. I also wish we were told to review the lecture that was not given (plantation lecture).

I think there should be some way (random quizes for instance) to ensure students are doing reading. I was not able to do as much reading as I should have, or would have liked, and would have been much more incentivized to do so if there were weekly quizes on the readings. Also, the syllabus lacked a clear reading schedule. It would be helpful if the readings were organized by the lectures they relate to.

This course is taught at a very high level in terms of plant taxonomy, forest dynamics, and geography. It would be wise for the professor to better explain these topics for the students with less or no training in these areas. The professor did answer questions when asked, but in the future, some better introductions to topics at a basic level would reduce class disruption due to very basic questions.

It should have been made clear from day one that students are responsible for all assigned readings not just the ones related to topics covered in lecture. If readings are supplemental they should be cleared designated as such. Sometimes the lectures were not concise, but were drawn-out and hard to understand what the main point was.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: More projects/figuring things out in the field
have 2 or 3 weekend long field trips.
The "labs" for this course are field trips, and they were essential for learning the principles taught in class.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is one of the fundamental forest science and management courses offered at the Forestry School. As such, it is a building block class of sorts, providing foundational knowledge in a number of topic areas within the realm of forest management.
This is a great course, but I think Stand Dynamics should be a prerequisite. A lot of students were struggling, and it felt like we spent a lot of time re-hashing basics so everyone should catch up.
It is an essential piece of the MF program
want to have strong understanding of forest ecology/management.

Incredibly useful for me as a research scientist--I learned about the art and magic of applied ecology, and improved my understanding of the interface between communities and stakeholder needs in the context of translating complicated and detailed empirical science.
I am very interested forestry, and this is the course to take. Very important!

I am not an MF and so this was an outlier course for me but very important for systems design. I know a lot of other MEMs would be interested in a forestry class for non MFs. However, this was a big commitment. Worth it for me but I wish others were less discouraged from taking it because of the level of effort.

This course was very helpful for me, as I had not taken any forest ecology or silviculture classes previously. It gave me a very good base understanding of forestry, upon which I will expand in the future.
This course is a requirement for my degree program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above.
Interested in applied land use
Although I am an MEM I took this as a foundational course for follow on forestry courses. It served that purpose.
to learn silviculture
I hope to work with communities to manage their forests sustainably, and silviculture is what it takes to do it.

I'm mostly interested in agriculture/agroforestry. I thought it would be useful to have a good foundation in silviculture. Even if I do not pursue anything related to forest, I thought the material was good to know/I enjoyed learning it. This course was highly recommended by past students.
As part of the MF curriculum, and to understand the science and practice of managing forests.
My studies at Yale involve all aspects of forests.
This course is a requirement for my degree program.
Just to do it, learn more about forestry

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes.
yes - excited to learn more
Yes, although learning by doing seems to be the only way to really learn silviculture, I have a much broader foundational understanding of forest ecology and silvicultural practice.
for the most part
I wish this class had been more challenging and covered the material at a more advanced level.
Absolutely yes
Definitely. It met the expectations.

Yes. I thought there might be a little more material on agroforestry and a little more on forestry in more tropical regions, but I understand that this could be covered in other courses/can't be covered in field trips.
Yes.
Yes

I believe that this course is invaluable to the forestry program. However, I think it could go more in-depth. Some students in the class clearly did not have a forestry background which made it difficult to delve farther into certain topics. Stand Dynamics should definitely be a prerequisite for Silviculture. I was disappointed at times because certain stand prescriptions were very basic. Some students in the class should have not have been in there as it negatively impacted the learning of many students.
exceeded

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: There was no group assignments but we did work as groups during the field trips.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The course is an exceptionally valuable exposure to the realm of scientific forest management, and essential for anyone interested in this field (pretty sure it's required anyway). The field trips can be a bit much, however, and while there aren't many assignments you'll still end up devoting a lot of time to this class beyond regular lecture periods. Be ready for the work to significantly ramp up in the last week.
Take Stand Dynamics first.
This course is a lot of work. be prepared

It's a get out what you put in kind of course. You can get by with relatively little effort just because the in class time commitment is so heavy, you would have to try not to learn something from Mark. But, if you take the field trips seriously and try to read on topics that need clarification you can come out of the course with a much more in depth understanding of the material.

- need strategy for paying attention through mark's entire lecture. Key thing to realize is there is usually one or two key points in the lecture engulfed in 2 hours of context. Use those key points as your guiding light. you will daze off and you will miss something that could be key, it's tough to know because it's all delivered in the same tone. - When Ann Camp says concise on her tests, she means 2 or 3 sentences. When Mark says concise on his tests he means 2 or 3 paragraphs. - For the tests, mark likes to throw curveballs at you. -for prescription, memorize new haven geology/soils
Do the readings!
Please take forest stand dynamics first, it will make your life a lot easier.
Do the readings prior to lecture.
This course is advertised as "Silviculture" however it delves deeply into plant ecology, geology/soils, politics, and conservation. It is among the most important courses I have ever taken.
The silviculture textbook is very well written and provides clarification for the lectures that are not very straight forward.
study hard and talk to Mark about mushroom and meadows
